shortdesc.p: Various methods may be used to customize the PDF output produced by the DITA Open Toolkit. Each of these approaches have advantages and shortcomings that should be considered when preparing a customization project. Some of these methods are considered “anti-patterns” with disadvantages that outweigh their apparent appeal. In most cases, you should create a custom PDF plug-in.

shortdesc.p: There are two common types of plug-ins: A plug-in that simply sets the DITA-OT parameters to be used when a PDF is generated, and a plug-in that overrides aspects of the base DITA-OT PDF transformation. A plug-in can, of course, do both of these things.

shortdesc.p: In cases that require substantial customizations, it is often useful to organize the files in a folder structure that mimics the hierarchy of the default PDF plug-in. shortdesc.p: The DITA Open Toolkit is an open-source implementation of the OASIS specification for the Darwin Information Typing Architecture. The toolkit uses Ant, XSLT, and Java to transform DITA content (maps and topics) into different deliverable formats.

topicmeta.linktext: Architecture of the DITA Open Toolkit
topicmeta.shortdesc: The DITA Open Toolkit is an open-source implementation of the OASIS specification for the Darwin Information Typing Architecture. The toolkit uses Ant, XSLT, and Java to transform DITA content (maps and topics) into different deliverable formats.

shortdesc.p: The DITA-OT implements a multi-stage, map-driven architecture to process DITA content. Each stage in the process examines some or all of the content; some stages result in temporary files that are used by later steps, while others stages result in updated copies of the DITA content. Most of the processing takes place in a temporary working directory; the source files themselves are never modified.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The DITA-OT implements a multi-stage, map-driven architecture to process DITA content. Each stage in the process examines some or all of the content; some stages result in temporary files that are used by later steps, while others stages result in updated copies of the DITA content. Most of the processing takes place in a temporary working directory; the source files themselves are never modified.

p.span: DITA-OT 3.0 provides a map-first preprocessing option as an alternative to the default preprocess operation. The method, which was introduced in DITA-OT 2.5 as an experimental feature, has been improved and is ready for use in many production scenarios. Map-first-preprocessing provides the same functionality as the default preprocess, but takes a different approach.

shortdesc.ph: DITA-OT 3.0 provides a map-first preprocessing option as an alternative to the default preprocess operation. The method, which was introduced in DITA-OT 2.5 as an experimental feature, has been improved and is ready for use in many production scenarios. Map-first-preprocessing provides the same functionality as the default preprocess, but takes a different approach.

shortdesc.p: The DITA-OT processing pipeline is implemented using Ant. Individual modules within the Ant script are implemented in either Java or XSLT, depending on such factors as performance or requirements for customization. Virtually all Ant and XSLT modules can be extended by adding a plug-in to the toolkit; new Ant targets may be inserted before or after common processing, and new rules may be imported into common XSLT modules to override default processing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The DITA-OT processing pipeline is implemented using Ant. Virtually all Ant and XSLT modules can be extended by adding a plug-in to the toolkit; new Ant targets may be inserted before or after common processing, and new rules may be imported into common XSLT modules to override default processing.

shortdesc.p: The order of processing is often significant when evaluating DITA content. Although the DITA specification does not mandate a specific order for processing, the DITA-OT has determined that performing filtering before conref resolution best meets user expectations. Switching the order of processing, while legal, may give different results.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The order of processing is often significant when evaluating DITA content. shortdesc.p: The pre-processing operation is a set of steps that typically runs at the beginning of every DITA-OT transformation. Each step or stage corresponds to an Ant target in the build pipeline; the preprocess target calls the entire set of steps.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The pre-processing operation is a set of steps that typically runs at the beginning of every DITA-OT transformation. Each step or stage corresponds to an Ant target in the build pipeline; the preprocess target calls the entire set of steps.

shortdesc.p: The gen-list step examines the input files and creates lists of topics, images, document properties, or other content. These lists are used by later steps in the pipeline. This step is implemented in Java.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The gen-list step examines the input files and creates lists of topics, images, document properties, or other content. These lists are used by later steps in the pipeline. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: The debug-filter step processes all referenced DITA content and creates copies in a temporary directory. As the DITA content is copied, filtering is performed, debugging information is inserted, and table column names are adjusted. This step is implemented in Java.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The debug-filter step processes all referenced DITA content and creates copies in a temporary directory. As the DITA content is copied, filtering is performed, debugging information is inserted, and table column names are adjusted. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: The mapref step resolves references from one DITA map to another. This step is implemented in XSLT.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The mapref step resolves references from one DITA map to another. This step is implemented in XSLT.

shortdesc.p: The branch-filter step filters topics using DITAVAL files defined in the map.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The branch-filter step filters topics using DITAVAL files defined in the map.

shortdesc.p: The copy-files step copies non-DITA resources to the output directory, such as HTML files that are referenced in a map or images that are referenced by a DITAVAL file. Which files are copied depends on the transformation type.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The copy-files step copies non-DITA resources to the output directory, such as HTML files that are referenced in a map or images that are referenced by a DITAVAL file. Which files are copied depends on the transformation type.

shortdesc.p: The keyref step examines all the keys that are defined in the DITA source and resolves the key references. Links that make use of keys are updated so that any @href value is replaced by the appropriate target; key-based text replacement is also performed, and the key definition list file is written to the temporary directory. This step is implemented in Java.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The keyref step examines all the keys that are defined in the DITA source and resolves the key references. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: The copy-to step makes a copy of original topic resources to new resources defined by the @copy-to attribute.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The copy-to step makes a copy of original topic resources to new resources defined by the copy-to attribute.

shortdesc.p: The conrefpush step resolves "conref push" references. This step only processes documents that use conref push or that are updated due to the push action. This step is implemented in Java.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The conrefpush step resolves "conref push" references. This step only processes documents that use conref push or that are updated due to the push action. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: The conref step resolves content references, processing only the DITA maps or topics that use the @conref attribute. This step is implemented in XSLT.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The conref step resolves content references, processing only the DITA maps or topics that use the conref attribute. This step is implemented in XSLT.

shortdesc.p: The profile step removes content from topics and maps based on the rules in DITAVAL files or the @print attribute setting. Output can differ based on when filtering is done.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The profile step removes content from topics and maps based on the rules in DITAVAL files or the print attribute setting. Output can differ based on when filtering is done.

shortdesc.p: The topic-fragment step expands content references to elements in the same topic and resolves references made with the <coderef> element. This step is implemented in SAX pipes.

shortdesc.p: The chunk step breaks apart and assembles referenced DITA content based on the @chunk attribute in maps. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: The move-meta-entries step pushes metadata back and forth between maps and topics. For example, index entries and copyrights in the map are pushed into affected topics, so that the topics can be processed later in isolation while retaining all relevant metadata. This step is implemented in Java.

shortdesc.p: This step collects links based on a map and moves those links into the referenced topics. The links are created based on hierarchy in the DITA map, the @collection-type attribute, and relationship tables. This step is implemented in XSLT and Java.

The module evaluates the DITAVAL against all flagging attributes, and adds DITA-OT–specific hints to the topic when flags are active. Any extended transformation type may use these hints to support flagging without adding logic to interpret the DITAVAL.
